bibl.title: Letter from Walter De Blois Briggs to Sidney Coe Howard, July 23, 1934

div1.p: Briggs, Jesse Lazear's son-in-law, congratulates Howard on his play. He offers a correction concerning Private Dean's willingness to participate in the experiment.

div1.head: Letter from Walter De Blois Briggs to Sidney Coe Howard, July 23, 1934
div1.opener:
Edgar Park House
Glendossary Lane,
Santa Barbara, California,
July 23, 1934.
Mr. Sidney Howard,
187 East 82nd Street,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Mr. Howard:
div1.p:
I have just finished reading your remarkably fine and inspiring play
“Yellow Jack” and I wish to congratulate you on writing such a splendid piece of
lasting work. As I am the son-in-law of Dr. Jesse Lazear, I am naturally more
interested in the play than most readers and I have therefore taken the liberty
of writing to you personally.

After reading your play, I felt that there was one incident in it
which I wanted to write you about in case you should offer the play to the moving
pictures. I feel that the incident dealing with the incident of Private Dean
should not be allowed to give the impression that Dean was tricked into the
experiment against his will for this most certainly was not the case. Dr. Aristides
Agramonte, who was himself present at the time Dean was asked to volunteer and was
an eye witness of the whole affair, has written an article in the Scientific Monthly
for December, 1915, which should disprove any other source for the incident. Dean,
Doctor Agramonte writes, when asked to take the mosquito bite replied, “Sure, I
ain't scared of 'em”. This statement of Dr. Agramonte's is surely adequate proof
in itself that Dean was not forced into the experiment against his will and I am
certain, out of all fairness to Dr. Lazear's memory and to his family now living,
you will be unwilling to allow any implication to stand, should the play appear in
the moving pictures, that there was anything unethical in this glorious experiment
for the benefit of humanity.

In regard to any other possible sources for the Private Dean incident,
I may add that a search has been made at the Johns Hopkins Library in Baltimore
and nothing has been found contradicting Dr. Agramonte's personal testimony of the
affair.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, Walter De Blois Briggs.
